TO BE DISTRIBUTED
Activities cards will be obtainable at the Barn on Thursday and Friday afternoons of
this week, Larkin H. Farinholt, president of the Student
Activities Council, announced
yesterday. These cards will
not be given out, however, unless the Treasurer's receipt is
presented.
Farinholt also stated that
these are the only days when
cards may be acquired and
urged all undergraduates to
bring their Treasurer's receipts on Thursday or Friday.

suffice as a large enough sample for accurate judgment. Nevertheless, we believe that one which affects the everyday conduct
of a person's life as closely and as often as English Composition I,
is a rather good criterion.

How much of the knowledge absorbed by the average student
in the average course does he retain permanently and how much
remains with him until examination time, only to be forgot as
completely as if it had never tortured his ears? Secondly, how
much of it does he use in any way whatsoever after he has completed the course?

* * * *
Editor-in-Chief

THEATRE

Other subjects may be of only cursory interest and importance; some may find their way into schedules merely because
they are "required." English Composition, however, despite the
more or less good-natured verbal darts directed at it from time to
time, is the one slice of the "collegiate education" that should do
the most toward making possible the cultural advantages that the
youth ostensibly seeks. After all, the basis of cultural development is the ability to express one's thoughts in language that is at
least presentable.

IMPRESSIVE IN DEFEAT
Ordinarily we are opposed to the use of the term "moral
victory"; it smacks somewhat of sour grapes and of trying to take
some of the credit away from one's opponents. But if such a
thing as a real moral victory exists, one was certainly scored by
Hopkins last Thursday. We have no intention of belittling Maryland by this statement, and even if we had such a desire it would
be impossible. The College Park eleven won its victory fairly in
one of the cleanest games of football we have ever seen, and it
won because it was the better team. The Old Liners may take in
welcome all of the laurels of their hard earned victory; sufficient

The gassing that the English language receives from the
bombs of the average undergrad would be sufficient to have put
to rout the entire German army during the World War. Many
people would flatly refuse to believe us if we told them that such
expressions as "Y'aint goin down town, are yuh?" or "He don't
care about it" could be heard ten to twenty times during any lunch
period at the Barn. "Did anybody bring their note-books?" is in
the repertoire of about fifty per cent of the student body.
* * * *

to swallow at the time, has no reason to cause any feeling other
than pride on the part of Hopkins men. From the start of the
game to the final whistle the team was impressive. Facing a much
heavier, experienced, and stronger opponent it never stopped fighting, out playing the surprised Maryland eleven in every department during the first half, and losing the lead in the second half
only after dogged resistance to irresistible power and driving force
of its rival. It would be unfair to pick out an individual hero.
Some were especially conspicuous, but every man on the field gave
his best.
Too much credit cannot be given to Coach Van Orman and
his assistants for building up a team capable of such an effort
despite the unusual scarcity of material. And those on the squad
who did not break into the line-up Thursday, and some of whom
have not played in a game all season should not be forgotten.
Their importance is great and their reward small. We also have
an idea that the brilliant showing at the Stadium would not have
been possible except for the spirit which was rampant on the campus after being latent for the first part of the season.
All this seems rather disjointed and perhaps pointless. Maybe
it is. Our real object, whether we achieved it or not was to express the thought that although we're sorry the team didn't win
we are iiroud of them and the showing they made.

Well, say the football fans, New Jersey may have her Willie and Henry, but Maryland has her Mike.
* * * *
And while we're speaking of football, we are reminded of an
incident that took place at the dance last Thursday night.
It seems that Gard Mallonee was dancing with a young lady
who had not attended many Hopkins functions. And said she to
Mal, "Are you a freshman?" "No," he replied, astonished, "I'm
Mallonee." "You are?" responded the girl, who was not a follower of football, "I'm glad to know you, I'm Libby Johnson !"

omy classes, stated that he did not
want the students to sign the pledge.
"I trust that you are all gentlemen
and that you will not cheat. Merely
signing your name signifies to me
that the work is your own."
Dr. Boas told his philosophy class
that he did not mind the students
studying and discusing the work together. "Written work should be
done alone, however," he said.
"Every man has his own sense of
honor, and upholding it is his business," stated Dr. Boas. "Cheating
only hurts the man himself."
"Working together on problems
is all right," stated Dr. Evans to his
statistics class. "Only if you feel
that the man you worked with has
helped you, state as much on your
paper. Nothing will be counted off
in marking."
Captain Strong of the Military
Department stated that he saw no
use in having students sign the
pledge. "If a man is of the type
that cheats, he will sign the pledge
anyway," said the captain. "I also
believe in the instructor staying in
the room, mainly to answer questions and see that order is observed."

Captain Robinson Promises Coach If
Enough Frosh Report

If the Freshmen want a class lacrosse team, they may have one,
Captain Robinson announced today.
Provided that enough frosh report
for practice during the next week
to make it worth while, a regular
coach will be appointed, and a team
organized.
Out of the forty men who came
to the varsity lacrosse organization
meeting last month, thirty reported
for practice the first day and the
number has now dwindled. "This
condition is deplorable. Is Hopkins, famed for its lacrosse teams,
to have only a mediocre team for
lack of support?" Captain Robinson wants to know.
"Many of the men who first came
out could not even catch or throw
a ball. In the short three days a
week practice since the last of October, all these men have developed
some ability at stickwork. But we
cannot make a team if we have no

DORM DOINGS
By order of the Board of Governors a meeting of all the residents was held recently. At this
assemblage Dr. Oliver, chairman of
the board, mentioned a few of the
quaint customs, existing in the dormitory, which are "unbecoming to
a gentleman." Practically every one
agreed that emptying fire extinguishers on fellow residents is one
of the childish customs which
should be abolished. A few other
dormitory traditions were likewise
discussed.
Residents were told to file all
complaints with the Executive Committee. However, the Board of
Governors has nothing to do with

Attend Teachers' Meeting
President Frank J. Goodnow, Dr.
Morgan Buchner, and Mr. Ryland
N. Dempster attended a meeting of

kind, was in a large part sponsored
by Johns Hopkins in collaboration
with the Maryland Department of
Education, and was held to discuss
matters connected with secondary
school education.

in science was the theme of this session, and Dr. Morris Meister of Columbia University, delivered an address on the "Kinds of Help High

Activities cards will be obtainable at the Barn on Thursday and Friday afternoons of

Activities Council, announced

not be given out, however, unless the Treasurer's receipt is

cards may be acquired and
urged all undergraduates to
bring their Treasurer's receipts on Thursday or Friday.

Ordinarily we are opposed to the use of the term "moral
victory"; it smacks somewhat of sour grapes and of trying to take
some of the credit away from one's opponents. But if such a
thing as a real moral victory exists, one was certainly scored by
Hopkins last Thursday. We have no intention of belittling Maryland by this statement, and even if we had such a desire it would
be impossible. The College Park eleven won its victory fairly in
one of the cleanest games of football we have ever seen, and it
won because it was the better team. The Old Liners may take in
welcome all of the laurels of their hard earned victory; sufficient

The gassing that the English language receives from the

people would flatly refuse to believe us if we told them that such
expressions as "Y'aint goin down town, are yuh?" or "He don't
care about it" could be heard ten to twenty times during any lunch

to swallow at the time, has no reason to cause any feeling other
than pride on the part of Hopkins men. From the start of the
game to the final whistle the team was impressive. Facing a much
heavier, experienced, and stronger opponent it never stopped fighting, out playing the surprised Maryland eleven in every department during the first half, and losing the lead in the second half
only after dogged resistance to irresistible power and driving force
of its rival. It would be unfair to pick out an individual hero.
Some were especially conspicuous, but every man on the field gave
his best.
Too much credit cannot be given to Coach Van Orman and
his assistants for building up a team capable of such an effort
despite the unusual scarcity of material. And those on the squad
who did not break into the line-up Thursday, and some of whom
have not played in a game all season should not be forgotten.
Their importance is great and their reward small. We also have
an idea that the brilliant showing at the Stadium would not have
been possible except for the spirit which was rampant on the campus after being latent for the first part of the season.
All this seems rather disjointed and perhaps pointless. Maybe
it is. Our real object, whether we achieved it or not was to express the thought that although we're sorry the team didn't win
we are iiroud of them and the showing they made.

Captain Robinson Promises Coach If
Enough Frosh Report

If the Freshmen want a class lacrosse team, they may have one,
Captain Robinson announced today.
Provided that enough frosh report
for practice during the next week
to make it worth while, a regular
coach will be appointed, and a team
organized.
Out of the forty men who came
to the varsity lacrosse organization
meeting last month, thirty reported
for practice the first day and the
number has now dwindled. "This
condition is deplorable. Is Hopkins, famed for its lacrosse teams,
to have only a mediocre team for
lack of support?" Captain Robinson wants to know.
"Many of the men who first came
out could not even catch or throw
a ball. In the short three days a
week practice since the last of October, all these men have developed
some ability at stickwork. But we
cannot make a team if we have no
material," Robinson states.
Captain Robinson wants to see
every man who has any athletic
ability at lacrosse practice next
Tuesday afternoon at four o'clock.
